Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Ken's Question to Dawkins, Wolpert, and Jones at GECCO 2007

> > Yes, the answers were indeed lacking. By the way, notice also how
> > they ignored the second part of my question: "How can evolution
> > search a space of such astronomical complexity?"

I think this question was at least partially addressed.  Dawkins seems
to suggest that the genome specifies mechanisms for building the
structure of the brain, and not the structure of the brain itself.  If
that's the case, then it isn't neccessary to search the space of
possible structures, correct?

That said, I've thought the same about the space defined by the genome
itself.  30,000 genes is 30,000 dimensions, and 4 billion years seems
like scant time to search it.  Two points which I rely on are (1)
Generations were occuring much more rapidly for microorganisms (and on
a much smaller genome), so a billion years is a long time and (2) The
search space isn't being searched for, say, a human-like solution all
at once.  Rather, it is searched through gradual complexification, so
that by the time humans are about to emerge, things like legs, lungs,
and circulatory systems have already been sorted out.  This is also
one reason I find NEAT so compelling.

On Jan 4, 2008 1:23 AM, Thomas Johnson <thomas.j.johnson@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
> These people must have email addresses, why not follow up with them that
> way? If they care about the question at all, I'm sure they'll give a more
> thoughtful response via email. If they don't care, well, then that's why you
> got such bad answers in the first place :-)
>
> Or, maybe you got bad answers because the answers actually reflect the
> current best guesses in their fields. In that case, the answers aren't
> really bad, it's just that people in other fields haven't been focusing
> their attention on this problem.
>
> Tom
>
>
>
> On Jan 4, 2008 12:09 AM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Yes, the answers were indeed lacking. By the way, notice also how
> > they ignored the second part of my question: "How can evolution
> > search a space of such astronomical complexity?"
> >
> > I was really disappointed that they didn't even venture into that
> > issue, because that's the really interesting question. Of course you
> > can always speculate on how a little can be converted to a lot by
> > talking about fractals and subroutines (after all, that's just
> > compression), but when you realize that we are talking about
> > *searching* a space of such mappings, it becomes far more complicated
> > and profound. The problem then becomes compounded by the fact that
> > not only must the representation be efficient but it must also warp
> > in meaningful ways, e.g. a biped should have biped children. How
> > does natural evolution manage to induce such a nicely structured
> > search space? Not a word was said on the matter.
> >
> > ken
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski"
> >
> >
> >
> > <petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
> > >
> > > Well, after I saw the video.. I don't know these people, they
> > should
> > > be very good scientists, but.. Their answers.. Sucked! Sorry about
> > > that language, but.. At least from my point of view, the answer
> > that
> > > DNA holds much more information seems the closest to the truth to
> > me.
> > > The composition of subroutines may bring a lot of complexity, but
> > not
> > > as close as this in nature, which was the question itself! In fact
> > we
> > > already know that..
> > > Hah, they even couldn't complete their answer, someone's wife just
> > > called.. They had to be more interested on this issue.
> > >
> > >
> > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djames@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Update: I asked Peter Bentley if it would be all right to upload
> > the
> > > > video to Google Video, and he said yes, as long as I linked back
> > to
> > > > his site and didn't edit it in any way. I didn't see a reason why
> > it
> > > > shouldn't be available as streaming video, since it's the venues
> > > exist
> > > > and it's a pain to download the torrent. Anyway, the link is here:
> > > >
> > > > http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=3201752343509862659&hl=en
> > > >
> > > > Ken's question is at 59:21 in the video.
> > > >
> > > > On Jan 2, 2008 12:58 AM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@> wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > Hi Derek, I had forgotten that they recorded that debate. I
> > > enjoyed
> > > > > having the opportunity to ask my question to such illustrious
> > > > > scientists, but like you, I was kind of disappointed with their
> > > > > answers. Like you said, they sort of answered accurately, but
> > > there
> > > > > was no real insight or thoughtfulness in what they said.
> > > > >
> > > > > It's interesting that you point out this exchange because I
> > > think it
> > > > > highlights a weakness in how biologists have been dealing with
> > > the
> > > > > question of complexity. It's such a fundamental question yet it
> > > > > hasn't really received the treatment it deserves, even from the
> > > > > field's luminaries. I think part of the problem is that a
> > genuine
> > > > > treatment requires a kind of algorithmic and representational
> > > theory,
> > > > > which is perhaps better attacked from a computational
> > > perspective,
> > > > > putting evolutionary computation researchers at an advantage
> > > because
> > > > > we think about search spaces, encodings, mappings, etc.
> > > routinely.
> > > >
> > > > Yes, I think you're right that EC researcher probably come at the
> > > > problem from an angle that might be more productive, but I'm
> > > > especially disappointed in Wolpert, who was the main voice for
> > > > developmental biology on the panel. Your question gets to issues
> > > that
> > > > a developmental biologist should primarily be interested in.
> > > >
> > > > Even if he didn't have specific insights related to the
> > development
> > > of
> > > > the human brain, he should have been able to give other examples
> > > with
> > > > which he was more familiar.
> > > >
> > > > By the way, I recently read Pasko Rakic's 1995 paper "A small
> > step
> > > for
> > > > the cell, a giant leap for mankind: a hypothesis of neocortical
> > > > expansion during evolution" from Trends in Neuroscience:
> > > >
> > > > http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6T0V-
> > > 3Y6PFXS-
> > >
> > 1P&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&view=c&_acct=C000050221
> > >
> > &_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=4eba37dec70f1bb0d9022402f97ae
> > > e43
> > > >
> > > > Here's the abstract:
> > > >
> > > > The more than 1000-fold increase in the cortical surface without a
> > > > comparable increase in its thickness during mammalian evolution is
> > > > explained in the context of the radial-unit hypothesis of cortical
> > > > development. According to the proposed model, cortical expansion
> > is
> > > > the result of changes in proliferation kinetics that increase the
> > > > number of radial columnar units without changing the number of
> > > neurons
> > > > within each unit significantly. Thus, mutation of a regulatory
> > gene
> > > (s)
> > > > that controls the timing and ratio of symmetric and asymmetric
> > modes
> > > > of cell divisions in the proliferative zone, coupled with radial
> > > > constraints in the distribution of migrating neurons, could
> > create
> > > an
> > > > expanded cortical plate with enhanced capacity for establishing
> > new
> > > > patterns of connectivity that are validated through natural
> > > selection.
> > > >
> > > > I'm personally working under the assumption that the cortical
> > > > minicolumn is the primary module, that repeatable bit of code that
> > > > Dawkins talked about, and there are a number of good work by
> > > > biologists out there, including Rakic, who give support to such an
> > > > idea.
> > > >
> > > > > Perhaps they were just being curt or did not take the audience
> > > > > seriously enough to elaborate their thoughts. Yet I find that
> > > > > explanation doubtful given that we were after all at
> > a "debate"
> > > about
> > > > > evolution and complexity, which is precisely the substance of
> > my
> > > > > question. I also agree that Dawkins seemed closest to really
> > > > > thinking about it, so I'd guess Dawkins would be very
> > interested
> > > in
> > > > > our area of EC if only there was an opportunity to tell him
> > about
> > > > > it. But I don't think he has a great deal of experience with it
> > > > > beyond his old Blind Watchmaker demo.
> > > >
> > > > I guess you didn't have a chance to corner him and talk things
> > over?
> > > > :) Dawkins does seem like he would be interested in a lot of the
> > > work
> > > > being presented at GECCO. Did he just show up for the panel, or
> > was
> > > he
> > > > around the conference at all?
> > > >
> > > > I was also thought the other really interesting exchange was at
> > > 33:45
> > > > in the video, when the question of whether or not you could
> > evolve a
> > > > mouse with feathered wings came up, and Wolpert and Jones both
> > said
> > > > no, while Dawkins seemed to say probably not, but not for any of
> > the
> > > > reasons the other guys came up with.
> > > >
> > > > --Derek
